title: Guidelines for Human-AI Interaction
authors: Amershi, S., Weld, D., Vorvoreanu, M., et al.
journal: CHI Conference on Human Factors in Computing Systems
keyPoints: 18 design guidelines for human-AI interaction, emphasizing user agency, transparency, and feedback mechanisms
keyHypotheses: Effective human-AI interaction requires clear communication of AI capabilities and limitations, user control over automation, and appropriate feedback mechanisms
strengths: Comprehensive framework based on extensive industry experience, practical guidelines for designers
weaknesses: Limited empirical validation, focuses on single-session interactions rather than sustained collaboration
citation: Amershi, S., Weld, D., Vorvoreanu, M., Fourney, A., Nushi, B., Collisson, P., ... & Horvitz, E. (2019). Guidelines for human-AI interaction. In Proceedings of the 2019 CHI conference on human factors in computing systems (pp. 1-13).
notes: Foundational work for human-AI interaction design principles

title: Artificial Intelligence and the Future of Work: Human-AI Symbiosis in Organizational Decision Making
keyPoints: Proposes human-AI symbiosis model, emphasizes complementary rather than competitive relationship, focuses on augmenting human decision-making
keyHypotheses: AI and humans have complementary strengths that can be leveraged through symbiotic relationships rather than replacement models
strengths: Strong theoretical framework, comprehensive analysis of complementary capabilities
weaknesses: Limited empirical evidence, focus on business contexts may not generalize to research settings
citation: Jarrahi, M. H. (2018). Artificial intelligence and the future of work: Human-AI symbiosis in organizational decision making. Journal of Business Research, 88, 530-537.
notes: Key theoretical framework for understanding complementary intelligence

title: Mental Models of AI Agents in a Cooperative Game Setting
authors: Gero, K.I., Kedzie, C., Reiter, J., McKeown, K.
keyPoints: Examines how humans form mental models of AI agents, identifies challenges in building shared understanding, studies coordination in cooperative tasks
keyHypotheses: Effective human-AI collaboration requires humans to develop accurate mental models of AI capabilities and limitations
strengths: Empirical study with controlled experimental design, focuses on collaborative rather than assistive AI
weaknesses: Limited to game-based tasks, short-term interactions only
citation: Gero, K. I., Kedzie, C., Reiter, J., & McKeown, K. (2020). Mental models of AI agents in a cooperative game setting. In Proceedings of the 2020 CHI Conference on Human Factors in Computing Systems (pp. 1-12).
notes: Important work on shared mental models in human-AI collaboration

title: CoAuthor: Designing a Human-AI Collaborative Writing Dataset for Exploring Language Model Capabilities
authors: Lee, M., Liang, P., Yang, Q.
journal: CHI Conference on Human Factors in Computing Systems
keyPoints: Studies interleaved human-AI writing collaboration, shows benefits of collaborative rather than sequential interaction patterns
keyHypotheses: Interleaved human-AI collaboration in writing tasks produces better outcomes than sequential human→AI or AI→human patterns
strengths: Novel interaction paradigm, empirical validation of interleaved collaboration benefits
weaknesses: Limited to writing tasks, short-term studies only
citation: Lee, M., Liang, P., & Yang, Q. (2022). CoAuthor: Designing a human-AI collaborative writing dataset for exploring language model capabilities. In Proceedings of the 2022 CHI Conference on Human Factors in Computing Systems (pp. 1-19).
notes: Evidence for benefits of interleaved collaboration patterns

title: Collaborative Intelligence: Humans and AI Are Joining Forces
keyPoints: Identifies three types of hybrid human-machine capabilities: amplifying, interacting, and embodying
keyHypotheses: Most business value from AI comes from collaborative intelligence where humans and machines work together rather than replacement scenarios
strengths: Practical framework with business applications, identifies specific hybrid capabilities
weaknesses: Business-focused rather than research-focused, limited empirical validation
citation: Wilson, H. J., & Daugherty, P. R. (2018). Collaborative intelligence: Humans and AI are joining forces. Harvard Business Review, 96(4), 114-123.
notes: Framework for hybrid human-machine capabilities in organizational contexts
